6.12.text:
PRESS CONFERENCE: CANTERBURY EARTHQUAKE - RELATED
ANNOUNCEMENT

7.12.text:
>>Hon. Bill English: Good morning everybody.
The Government has repeatedly said since the

11.49.text:
February earthquake in Christchurch that we
stand ready to do whatever is needed to rebuild

17.27.text:
Christchurch. It is one of our most important
priorities. We are focused on helping the

25.33.text:
residents of Christchurch get through the
initial emergency and, of course, the aftermath.

32.51.text:
Today's announcement is another step in helping
Canterbury residents to rebuild their homes

40.70.text:
and their lives.
We are today announcing a financial support

45.24.text:
package for AMI Insurance so that the tens
of thousands of homeowners and policyholders

54.55.text:
in Christchurch can have certainty that their
claims will be met. This will help to ensure

62.90.text:
an orderly rebuild of Christchurch in the
aftermath of these two earthquakes. The support

70.36.text:
package will be called on only as a last resort
if AMI's own reserves have been exhausted

79.14.text:
by the claims that they are liable to meet.
The Crown will have the option to take control

87.01.text:
of the company before that point if it believes
it is in the public interest.

93.21.text:
The support package will provide certainty
that the homeowners can have their claims

99.13.text:
met. At the same time it will give AMI the
time and the opportunity to find a market

107.86.text:
solution to the financial challenges that
it faces as a result of the earthquake. If

115.41.text:
the package is called on, it could involve
the Government investing up to $500 billion

121.53.text:
of equity in AMI, with the right to take ownership
and assume control of the company at any time

132.03.text:
with the payment of $100 million.
AMI is New Zealand's second largest residential

139.49.text:
insurer with 485,000 policyholders around
New Zealand. It has 85,000 policyholders in

148.61.text:
Christchurch alone - about 35 percent of the
residential insurance market.

153.77.text:
AMI approached the Government on 9 March concerned
that it was uncertain whether its reserves

162.43.text:
and reinsurance might not be sufficient to
cover the total value of claims resulting

170.09.text:
from the Canterbury earthquakes. Since then,
officials have been working closely with the

175.76.text:
company to gather information about a range
of issues and to consider the best options

182.39.text:
for the taxpayer and for AMI's policyholders.
AMI is a mutual company so it is owned by

193.49.text:
its policyholders. There are no shareholders,
there are no depositors, it is owned by the

199.82.text:
policyholders. It is the Government's judgment
that a support package was necessary to give

207.13.text:
certainty to the policyholders. This applies
to all AMI policyholders across New Zealand,

214.79.text:
not just those in Canterbury; so for AMI policyholders
across New Zealand this support package means

222.61.text:
that business as usual can continue.
Because of the uncertainty around the cost

230.19.text:
of the earthquake damage, it is too early
to tell whether AMI will have sufficient resources

237.80.text:
to cover the cost of the claims. In fact,
the full extent of the claims on AMI will

244.37.text:
remain unclear for several months, both the
number of claims and the cost of individual

251.05.text:
claims, so Ministers have decided to act now
to provide a backstop for policyholders to

259.59.text:
give them certainty and so that the rebuilding
of Christchurch can continue without the disruption

267.86.text:
of a major financial issue. We want to make
sure that the rebuild is not jeopardised by

277.72.text:
potential solvency or liquidity issues, and
to maintain confidence in AMI and in the insurance

285.54.text:
sector. AMI has confirmed to the Government
that it will seek an alternative commercial

292.81.text:
arrangement to replace the Government's support
facility as soon as possible. The package

299.76.text:
we are announcing today gives the company
time to achieve that.

304.48.text:
I'll just run you through the main features
of the support package. You'll have the detail

310.50.text:
in the background material that has been handed
out. But I do want to repeat that the package

316.03.text:
will be used only as a last resort, if the
company's own reserves have been exhausted

322.76.text:
meeting its earthquake claims, with the Crown
reserving the right to take control of the

330.79.text:
company before that time if it is in the public
interest.

335.75.text:
Under the policyholder support package, AMI
has paid the Crown $15 million up front as

342.42.text:
an establishment fee for this support package.
The AMI has issued convertible preference

348.63.text:
shares to the Crown, but the Crown has not
yet paid for them. AMI tell us that if payment

355.99.text:
is required, it may not need to happen for
2 years. Payment will happen only if AMI's

363.69.text:
own resources are depleted below the level
prudent for an insurance business, or if the

369.25.text:
Crown decides it is in the public interest
to make the payment. The Crown's $500 million

375.59.text:
policy support package will provide the company
with the platform from which to explore options

381.43.text:
to get capital from other sources. If the
arrangement is called on by AMI, and it later

390.53.text:
becomes clear that AMI can pay all likely
claims, then it will exit the support arrangement

398.62.text:
by repaying the Crown, along with any dividends
that are owing on the shares.

405.54.text:
It is important to understand that while the
Crown enters this kind of arrangement very

414.55.text:
reluctantly, the alternative to this package
could have been a great deal of uncertainty

421.51.text:
and disruption both in the insurance market
and in Christchurch. We could have left many

429.89.text:
thousands of AMI policyholders with their
houses destroyed or significantly damaged

438.53.text:
without insurance cover or the financial resources
they need to rebuild. Uncertainty about the

447.96.text:
financial viability of the company could have
led to long delays in processing claims, many

453.66.text:
claims only being partially met, and AMI's
customers, perhaps, having difficulty getting

463.02.text:
insurance cover for future risks.
This is an unusual, in fact, a unique situation

472.49.text:
that has required a special response. In considering
its options, the Government has been acutely

480.26.text:
aware of the need to protect the interests
of taxpayers who are already facing significant

486.55.text:
costs from the Canterbury earthquake and the
finance company collapses. The Government

492.63.text:
believes that this package allows us to take
every possible step to minimise the cost to

498.68.text:
taxpayers at the same time as meeting the
very real need for certainty for thousands

504.75.text:
of AMI policyholders in Christchurch.
Finally, events like this show the importance

512.57.text:
of getting the Government's finances back
into good shape as soon as possible. We remain

518.21.text:
committed to returning to Budget surpluses,
and these events do not alter that commitment.

525.29.text:
Just a final point: there will be the temptation
to label this particular package as a bailout

536.52.text:
of a company. We want to stress there are
no shareholders in this company. The only

544.35.text:
people who will benefit from Government support
are the policyholders, because the company

550.96.text:
is completely owned by the policyholders.
So there are no depositors, there are no shareholders,

561.18.text:
and no one who does not own a policy with
AMI will benefit in the long run from this

569.44.text:
package. It is intended to provide support
for those thousands of people in Christchurch

576.47.text:
who bought insurance in good faith and who
now face the problem of substantial damage

585.03.text:
or loss to their major, and, in fact, probably
only, major personal asset, and their life

591.59.text:
savings, and it is for that reason that the
Government has seen fit to support this company.

598.78.text:
Any questions?
>>Media: How likely is it that you'll have

602.35.text:
to pump this $500 million of equity into the
company, given what you know behind the scenes

609.30.text:
about the state of the books within AMI?
>>English: That's uncertain. There's so much

614.28.text:
uncertainty here about the number of claims
and the nature of those claims. There's a

621.14.text:
range of estimates that we've been provided
with from the company and the Reserve Bank,

627.31.text:
and those estimates are estimates of the excessive
claims over the money available to meet them.

636.42.text:
Those estimates range from zero - that is,
the company may be able to meet all the claims

642.65.text:
- through to about $1 billion more claims
than they are able to meet. But there's a

649.69.text:
great deal of uncertainty about what the actual
number is likely to be. We've structured this

656.08.text:
package in a way that gives the company very
strong incentives to successfully trade through

665.17.text:
to the point where no taxpayer support is
necessary.

667.90.text:
>>Media: Why didn't they have cover for this?
They take premiums every year. Are you satisfied

668.90.text:
that the company has been properly run and
that they might have had sufficient cover

679.26.text:
to meet this?
>>English: You need to talk to the company

684.60.text:
about their policies. We will be appointing
a director and advisers to the company who

693.33.text:
have the right to attend any meeting of the
company. We reserve the right to take control

699.73.text:
of the company at any time. In respect of
the situation in Christchurch, it is pretty

708.73.text:
unique. There's a combination of circumstances
here where the company has a concentration

717.62.text:
of policyholders in Christchurch compared
with other centres in New Zealand. Christchurch

722.59.text:
has had two major earthquakes in 6 months.
The company is a mutual, which means it can't

730.11.text:
go and raise capital easily; it has to essentially
sell itself if it wants to get capital into

736.72.text:
the company. So all those factors have combined
to put them in this situation. At some stage,

742.59.text:
we will need to go back and have a look to
see whether the management have run the company

750.24.text:
prudently and whether they've complied with
industry standards and the regulation. Up

755.21.text:
to now, there's no indication that they haven't,
but clearly the Crown's getting alongside

760.86.text:
the board of management here and in another
few months we'll have a much better understanding

764.80.text:
of how it's run.
>>Media: Are there any other New Zealand

774.25.text:
insurance companies that have come to you
and said they've got problems, or are they

777.46.text:
predominantly owned overseas and wouldn't
be eligible for any help?

778.46.text:
>>English: There's no indication that other
companies are in difficulty. The Reserve Bank

782.20.text:
and Treasury, of course, are taking a close
interest in the insurance sector, and I can

787.13.text:
confirm we're not in talks with anybody else.
>>Media: So what's your advice, or what level

794.96.text:
of comfort can you provide, to policyholders
in AMI whose insurance with them may be coming

800.50.text:
up quite shortly and they might be thinking
“I'm going to [10:13:46] elsewhere.”?

805.20.text:
>>English: The Government support arrangement
means for policyholders it's business as usual.

810.32.text:
So it is effectively a guarantee that any
claims they make will be met.

817.67.text:
>>Media: So will this announcement encourage
people to continue to hold insurance with

821.51.text:
AMI or discourage them?
>>English: Well, it will be up to them. This

827.84.text:
is a company that's had a reasonably strong
brand and has attracted almost half a million

833.04.text:
New Zealanders to it. The support package
means that their claims will be met.

838.97.text:
>>Media: Can you explain how the $500 million
support package and the $100 million that

842.67.text:
you could pay just to take control of the
company work? Is one a subset of the other?

849.16.text:
Secondly, would it cease to be a mutual if
the Government exercised its options? Would

857.43.text:
you just become the 100 percent shareholder?
>>English: The $500 million is essentially

858.71.text:
uncalled capital, and we would be paying up
$100 million of it. We have the choice to

865.97.text:
elect to pay up $100 million of it at any
time, and if we pay that $100 million, we

872.17.text:
take full ownership and control of it.
>>Media: So if they call for $100 million,

877.85.text:
that's the same thing, is it? As soon as they've
called for that $100 million, you own it?

884.91.text:
>>English: If they call for $1, then we can
effectively take ownership of the company.

889.28.text:
So that puts a strong incentive on the current
board and management that if they want to

894.54.text:
continue the business as it is now, then they
need to find another commercial solution,

903.50.text:
such as someone else who will put capital
into the company.

906.35.text:
>>Media: What's the trigger for you and the
Government to take over? Is it that first

914.65.text:
dollar that's called or is it when it gets
over a hundred or is there no set figure?

915.65.text:
>>English: The trigger for us is whenever
we think it's in the public interest to take

919.20.text:
control of it.
>>Media: And the second part of my question

923.29.text:
was would it cease to be a mutual at that
point? You'd have 100 percent control?

925.83.text:
>>English: Well, it would become a Government-owned
company, so, yes, it would cease to be a mutual,

930.84.text:
because the policyholders wouldn't then have
the opportunity to influence the ownership

935.19.text:
of it. The effective owner of it is a trust
deed company, and the policyholders are beneficiaries

941.86.text:
of the trust deed. I wouldn't want to get
into the technicalities of how the Crown would

949.09.text:
actually do that; what I can say is that we
have the ability at any time to take total

956.44.text:
control of the company.
>>Media: What would have been the consequences

962.90.text:
of giving nothing?
>>English: You have in the mix here directors

969.70.text:
who need to be able to say that they're trading
while solvent, who can pass a solvency test

977.36.text:
on any one day; ratings agencies who of course
are paying quite a bit of attention to the

985.67.text:
solvency and liquidity of insurance companies
at the moment; and of course policyholders.

989.91.text:
It is our view that uncertainty for any of
those parties could have triggered a series

998.50.text:
of events that would lead to quite a chaotic
situation in Christchurch, which would be

1004.57.text:
very damaging for the policyholders themselves
and also make it very difficult to get on

1012.24.text:
with the rebuild of Christchurch, if you had
significant financial problems with an insurer

1017.74.text:
of a third of the residential area of the
city.

1020.12.text:
>>Media: How many claims has AMI had in both
earthquakes so far, do you know? And how many

1034.30.text:
are they maybe expecting as a result and have
been received?

1036.85.text:
>>English: I can't tell you those numbers.
They've got 85,000 policyholders there. I

1039.61.text:
think they are still trying to get an estimate
of how many claims they would receive. You'd

1046.14.text:
be best to direct that inquiry to the company.
>>Media: Are you happy with how the rating

1048.95.text:
agency and Best have performed? Because if
you look at AMI's rating at the moment, you

1052.98.text:
wouldn't expect it would need the Government
to back it up to the tune of $500 million.

1060.62.text:
>>English: As I will explain further later
in the day, we were approached on 9 March,

1070.11.text:
prompted by the fact that the board was going
to be meeting with the rating agency within

1077.31.text:
a few days. We supplied a letter of support
to AMI to take to their discussions with the

1089.14.text:
ratings agency, I think on 12 or 13 March.
That letter of support enabled a discussion

1098.07.text:
where they were downgraded a couple of notches.
Without that letter of support, it may have

1104.40.text:
been a different situation.
>>Media: Does this create a level playing

1105.40.text:
field, in that here is one insurance company
that has effectively a Government guarantee

1124.49.text:
now? Does that skew the field in terms of
the other insurance companies? Are you going

1125.49.text:
to have to provide this guarantee for them?
>>English: We certainly wouldn't be looking

1126.49.text:
to provide it for anyone else, and in this
case we would hope that it's not activated,

1132.12.text:
because the company has been able to find
other solutions. We've gone into this situation

1142.58.text:
very reluctantly, and that's one of the reasons.
But the fact is that if we didn't offer support,

1149.97.text:
we would have thousands of homeowners in Christchurch
who'd be left in the lurch with no effective

1156.70.text:
insurance and a severely disrupted rebuild
effort. Now, if it weren't for the unique

1162.88.text:
combination of circumstances that arise here,
we would not be looking to support this company.

1168.29.text:
>>Media: In your judgment, how large a capital
sum is required in order to put the thing

1173.53.text:
back on its feet?
>>English: Well, we've subscribed for $500

1177.34.text:
million of uncalled capital, and that number
is intended to provide them a strong enough

1185.21.text:
platform to go to the market as a going concern
- that is, with a reasonable credit rating

1193.83.text:
with the licensing under the new prudential
supervision regime - and find some commercial

1201.54.text:
solutions. But the top priority is that it
provides sufficient support for the company

1208.47.text:
that claimants can know that their claims
will be paid.

1212.95.text:
>>Media: Why would anyone be interested in
even investing in a thing that has to have

1215.62.text:
this level of Government support?
>>English: Well, that is going to be tested.

1221.78.text:
We need to keep in mind here that it has got
400,000 other policyholders who aren't caught

1227.90.text:
up in the Christchurch earthquake and a brand
that may have some value. But that will be

1234.40.text:
tested in the market. This package is designed
to give them the time, and the market, a sense

1240.92.text:
that the company is stabilised to see whether
there is value there.

1245.64.text:
>>Media: Is that potentially a billion dollars
worth of claims over and above reinsurance

1248.04.text:
money in reserves, and the $500 million you
are talking about now is only going to meet

1250.24.text:
half of that?
>>English: We are trying to deal with a situation

1261.71.text:
of real uncertainty where the company is still
trying to get some firm knowledge about the

1274.85.text:
extent to which its claimants are affected
- are they concentrated in east Christchurch,

1279.82.text:
for instance. There has been some speculation
that their claimants are concentrated in that

1283.60.text:
part of the city, which would mean that they
may have more than their fair share - we simply

1287.82.text:
don't know. As I said, the estimates we have
seen cover a huge range; anywhere from zero

1296.05.text:
through to a billion of excess claims.
>>Media: What is the upper limit of the Government's

1303.23.text:
liability if a shortfall was to be towards
the upper limit, towards a billion dollars?

1315.01.text:
>>English: The upper limit of the liability
will depend entirely on how many claims there

1318.99.text:
are and the cost of those claims. So the liability
is determined by the claimants, the policyholders,

1327.17.text:
the homeowners in Christchurch - that is who
will determine it.

1329.77.text:
>>Media: Are you prepared to put more than
$500 million in if that's required?

1332.07.text:
>>English: Look, there shouldn't be any uncertainty
about the intent of this package. The intent

1340.26.text:
of it is to ensure that all claims can be
met. At the moment we can't be certain what

1347.34.text:
that cost is.
>>Media: So if in fact that upper limit of

1350.81.text:
$1 billion, or that upper estimate of $1 billion
in shortfall on the claims there was to eventuate,

1362.07.text:
it is likely the Government would have to
find that amount of money?

1369.70.text:
>>English: Yes, that is possible.
>>Media: So we could be exposed to up to

1372.24.text:
a billion dollars?
>>English: The estimates we have are anywhere

1373.32.text:
from zero exposure to a billion. Those are
the estimates we've been given. Over the next

1379.58.text:
few months as more information becomes available
we will be able to get a firmer grip on it.

1386.81.text:
The second thing is that whatever equity the
Crown puts in as of today there is the possibility

1394.40.text:
of recovery of some or all of it through potentially
a sale of the business - bearing in mind that

1403.44.text:
outside of Christchurch this company has another
400,000 policyholders who are paying premiums

1412.55.text:
every month, every year, and this company
has been profitable in the past.

1417.63.text:
>>Media: Let me get this clear: the $500
million is not a cap; you are flexible in

1426.34.text:
a sense that if the call was up to a billion
dollars the Government, hypothetically, would

1431.24.text:
go that far?
>>English: Yes, well, the intent of the package

1432.24.text:
is to give certainty that all the claims that
are made in Christchurch but also in the rest

1438.34.text:
of the country will be met. Over the next
couple of months we will get a clearer idea

1445.92.text:
of whether those claims can be met entirely
by the resources of the company. This is a

1454.55.text:
company that's got around $600 million of
reinsurance and $350 million worth of cash.

1461.42.text:
So they've got close to a billion dollars
available to them to meet claims. We've yet

1464.88.text:
to see whether there'll be more claims than
a billion dollars.

1465.98.text:
>>Media: So why have you said $500 million
today in all your press kit here when, really,

1467.59.text:
you know that there could be a billion shortfall
and that you're prepared to go as far as a

1478.93.text:
billion dollars?
>>English: Because it is uncertain as to

1483.48.text:
whether it's going to be zero or a billion
and we wanted to get an arrangement in place

1488.96.text:
that would give them sufficient equity to
be able to continue business as usual. So

1494.45.text:
there is no question of their ability to meet
claims probably for the next couple of years.

1501.22.text:
And to give them the opportunity to go to
the market and take the time to find a commercial

1506.76.text:
solution which, ideally, would take the Government
out, put someone else's capital in and then

1512.72.text:
taxpayers wouldn't face any loss at all. I
must stress the uncertainty about two things

1518.31.text:
here: one is the scale of the claims and the
second is what value others in the market

1526.17.text:
may see in the company.
>>Media: So will you have to put this as

1530.05.text:
a contingent liability on your books? I mean,
are you up for $1 billion on your books now?

1536.22.text:
>>English: Well, the accountants will have
to work out, as they have had to before, just

1540.95.text:
what potential loss there is. An investment
by the Crown isn't a loss; it's an investment

1548.30.text:
by the Crown. But there may be potential losses
associated with it. We're running out of time

1555.90.text:
in the construction of the Budget to be able
to put in a provision that is based on strong

1563.26.text:
information, but within 2 or 3 months we should
have a clearer idea, and then you'll see those

1569.40.text:
provisions made through the monthly accounts,
as has been happening with South Canterbury

1573.66.text:
Finance.
>>Media: But that's just an accounting issue,

1574.66.text:
isn't it? It would be a loss, wouldn't it?
If you paid out $1 billion, and you put $1

1583.24.text:
billion into it, you'd end up with a company
that paid all its claims and wasn't worth

1590.37.text:
anything, or was worth very little.
>>English: I think the challenge here is

1591.37.text:
just estimating it in the face of uncertainty.
AMI will take a while to find out what claims

1594.46.text:
it's going to get. Then there'll be other
issues come into it, such as the extent of

1600.54.text:
reinsurance for future claims and testing
in the market about what value there might

1607.05.text:
be in the company. So even though this issue's
been under discussion for getting up to 4

1615.41.text:
weeks, there is really no more certainty than
we've been able to give you today about what

1623.41.text:
it would actually cost the taxpayer, if anything.
So we're just giving you the best estimates

1628.90.text:
we've been given in the face of very significant
uncertainty.

1632.07.text:
>>Media: What do you say to someone who's
going to go down to the nearest AMI office

1637.38.text:
today and sign up for a new insurance package
on their house, contents, or car? Can they

1642.16.text:
be confident they'll be paid out?
>>English: Yes, they can be. That's the intent

1644.21.text:
of the package.
>>Media: You're effectively taking on liability

1647.06.text:
for the rest of AMI's insurance business outside
of Christchurch, as well. What's the size

1651.27.text:
of that? What's their typical claims payout
in a year when we don't have these kinds of

1657.77.text:
disasters?
>>English: You'd be best to go to the company

1664.22.text:
to get the detail of that information. The
package enables them to continue business

1672.10.text:
as usual. They have put aside money to meet
ongoing claims. My understanding is that roughly

1680.66.text:
$100 million to $200 million of claims would
be business as usual. So the discussion about

1689.17.text:
their shortfall in resources or uncertainty
about resources does allow for maintaining

1697.40.text:
the ongoing business and the business as usual
claims, as well as trying to cover the Christchurch

1705.13.text:
claims.
>>Media: So you are liable for every AMI

1709.55.text:
policyholder, no matter where in New Zealand
